info.p: "CSV is one of the most popular formats for publishing data on the web. It is concise, easy to understand by both humans and computers, and aligns nicely to the tabular nature of most data. But CSV is also a poor format for data. There is no mechanism within CSV to indicate the type of data in a particular column, or whether values in a particular column must be unique. It is therefore hard to validate and prone to errors such as missing values or differing data types within a column." (from the "CSV on the Web: A Primer")
Issues to be aware of when submitting CSV-formatted data:

ul.li: Line endings must be consistent: do not submit files with mixed Windows / Unix endings! (Quick hints: dos2linux, linux2dos; adjust save options in your editor; use a HEX editor to spy on the endings; see more e.g. at Cybermindworks).
Watch out for (and preferably weed out) extra columns and extra lines (this is part of the general etiquette when submitting data to a centre; there's humans on the other side)
Contact your target centre to make sure if they have any particular requirements concerning CSV, if it is not stated clearly in the SIS.
